ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Happy Birthday, Moon. We followed Bear as he talked to the moon about his birthday. We also learned about a new kind of word called a compound word.
Remember, a compound word is a big word made of two smaller words. I will show you a picture of a compound word. Then we’ll take the word apart and put it back together!
All of these words relate to our book or to this week’s concept question: What do we do during the day and at night?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Some of these words are words we already knew. Were you surprised to find little words inside them? Why or why not? Sometimes when we look at the little words inside of bigger words, we can figure out what the bigger word means.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Younger or developmentally delayed children may need more support to complete the activity. Say the word normally, then say it slowly, emphasizing each word. Finally, say the first part of the word, and invite the child to complete it for you.

Challenge students to identify other compounds—for example, pencil sharpener, watermelon, school bus, merry-go-round. Children who are starting to understand word forms will be able to see that some are one big word and others have a space or a hyphen.

Tell the group that compound words exist in many languages. Learn some compound words in your multilingual learners’ home language. For example, cumpleaños, or birthday, is made of two words, cumple (completes) and años (years). Invite multilingual learners to separate the two words.

Provide the group with paper and drawing tools. Hand a card to pairs of students. Have each pair draw a different part of the compound word. Then have them put the cards side by side and tell how the pictures go together to make the bigger word.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials You will need paper and crayons as well as building blocks in order for children to demonstrate the goal listed on the card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Happy Birthday, Moon. We saw how hard Bear worked to talk to the moon.
We learned the word goal. Let’s revisit that word since that has something to do with today’s activity.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the goal Vocabulary Card to review the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Now that we’re getting close to the end of the year, we have all achieved some important goals. Today you are going to act out the goal you feel most proud about reaching!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Spread out the activity cards on a table or display them on a shelf. Ask children what they can do now that makes them proud. It does not have to be one of the pictured goals. But if a child points to a card, pick it up and ask the questions on the card. Otherwise, ask the child to act out the new ability and talk about it while doing so.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation, or ask the child what his or her next goal might be.
Repeat Continue the game using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Earlier today, we talked about how important it is to keep going to reach our goals. At first, reaching a goal can be hard, but if we keep at it, we can get there.
When we reach a goal, it’s great to share what we’ve done with others because we are proud. Who do you tell when you reach a goal?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Although the activity cards show a range, some children may not see their own skills shown. Keep in mind the abilities of younger or developmentally delayed children in your group. Be ready to remind them about abilities they’ve mastered recently!

Some literacy skills, like writing your name, can be difficult to act out without materials. Have some props ready, like an Alphabet Book and paper and crayons, for students who want to show off new abilities in literacy.

Give children extra time for peer-to-peer conversation. Encourage children to work in pairs, talking about each of their goals. Remind them to take turns speaking, with one person actively listening while the other speaks. Remind children that it’s okay to use all the languages they both know when talking with a peer who is also multilingual.

Consider doing this activity in the large-group space or outdoors, where children can really show off newly achieved gross-motor milestones. This activity would give them the opportunity to show how they can pedal a tricycle, pump on a swing, or go across the monkey bars. Big body play encourages engagement, activates memory, and helps develop children’s strength.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Happy Birthday, Moon. We followed Bear as he went shopping for a birthday present for the Moon. Who remembers what he bought?
We learned the word fit. Let’s revisit that word since that has something to do with today’s activity.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the fit Vocabulary Card to review the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Bear thought the hat he gave to the moon fit perfectly! But did it really fit? Let’s look at some pictures. We will sort them into two groups: things that fit, and things that do not fit.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card to one child and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the game, showing the next picture card to the next child.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Some of these pictures showed how things fit on our bodies, like the hat fit on Bear’s head. Which cards were those? Other cards didn’t have anything to do with clothes. We can talk about pieces that fit into puzzles or turtles that fit on a log!

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-card_run-in_hed: Talk About Things That Don’t Fit
ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: For every thing that fit, we had examples of things that did not fit. Which cards were those? What other words can we use to describe these cards?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Show the child three cards at a time, including two things that “fit” and one thing that “does not fit.” Ask, Which picture shows something that fits? Then ask, How do you know? Finally, ask, Which shows something that does not fit? How do you know?

Show the child a pair of cards that are somehow related—two cards showing turtles, or two cards showing things that fit. Ask the child to describe the two cards in one long sentence. Share this model: This card shows clothes that fit, and this card shows clothes that don’t.

Multilingual learners in your class may struggle with the helping verb do/does as in does not fit and may prefer to use physical response instead of speaking. Invite English learners to move the card to one of two columns: “fits” or “does not fit.” Talk about what the child is doing. For example, say, Those clothes do not fit. Can you say do not fit?

Students who need sensory support may enjoy sorting objects that fit and do not fit. Cover the table with paired objects, such as two fitting puzzle pieces and two mismatched puzzle pieces, or a child’s hat and an oversized hat. Invite children to work with these objects while describing whether they fit or do not fit, and tell why.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we looked at the Big Chart of Big Ideas. We saw examples of things that happen in the daytime, in the nighttime, in the mountains, in the country, and in the city.
In this activity, we will talk about things that people and animals do. We will sort these things into daytime or nighttime groups.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and use the text on the back to ask if the activity happens in the daytime or the nighttime. Offer extra support or challenge as needed.
Extend Use the last question to extend the conversation.
Sort Give the picture card to a child to line up in one of two columns: “daytime” or “nighttime.”
Repeat Continue the activity, showing the next card to the next child.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: What did we notice about the daytime activities? What did we notice about the nighttime activities? What do some animals do when we are sleeping?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Show the child three cards at a time, showing two things that happen in the daytime and one thing that happens at night. Ask, Which of these is different from the other two? Then ask, How do you know?

Show the pair of cards showing children in day and night. Ask, What is the same and what is different about these pictures? Encourage children to say two things about the cards in one sentence, for example: This is children in the day, and this is a child at night.

Encourage multilingual learners in your class to share the sounds that people make when they snore or the sounds that each animal shown in a card makes when it is awake and active. Children will enjoy learning that animals around the world “speak” different languages.

Encourage children to act out activities they see on each card as they also describe them in words. Let children curl up and snore or pretend to fly through the air like an owl. Big body play encourages engagement and activates memory. It also helps develop children’s strength and coordination.
